page.title: 8.5.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will build on the idea that both graphing and rewriting quadratic equations in the form of expression = 0 are useful strategies for solving equations. You will also review the ties between the zeros of a function and the horizontal intercepts of its graph, which you began exploring in an earlier unit.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain why dividing by a variable to solve a quadratic equation is not a good strategy.
  • Explain why quadratic equations can have no solutions and explain why there are none.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 8.5.1: Reviewing Zero Product Property
  • 8.5.2: Interpreting Graphs to Solve Quadratic Equations
    • 8.5.2: Self Check
    • 8.5.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.5.3: Choosing an Effective Strategy to Solve Quadratic Equations
    • 8.5.3: Self Check
    • 8.5.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.5.4: Analyzing Errors When Solving Quadratic Equations

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 8.5.5: Practice
  • 8.5.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 8.5.1: Reviewing Zero Product Property
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Decide whether each statement is true or false.

  1. 3 is the only solution to \(x^2−9=0\).

Correct! False. There are two solutions because there are two numbers that can be squared to get 9. Both 3 and –3 are possible solutions.

False. There are two solutions because there are two numbers that can be squared to get 9. Both 3 and –3 are possible solutions.

  1. A solution to \(x^2+25=0\) is –5. 

Correct! False. There is no solution to \(x^2+25=0\) because no real number can be squared to get –25.

False. There is no solution to \(x^2+25=0\) because no real number can be squared to get –25.

  1. \(x(x−7)=0\) has two solutions.

Correct! True. There are two factors, 0 and 7, that could make the product of the expression 0.

True. There are two factors, 0 and 7, that could make the product of the expression 0.

  1. 5 and –7 are the solutions to \((x−5)(x+7)=12\).

Correct! False. The product of the two factors is not 0, so we cannot solve it using the zero product property (which gives 5 and –7 as solutions). If we evaluate the expression \((x−5)(x+7)\) at those two values, the result will be 0, not 12.

False. The product of the two factors is not 0, so we cannot solve it using the zero product property (which gives 5 and –7 as solutions). If we evaluate the expression \((x−5)(x+7)\) at those two values, the result will be 0, not 12.

page.title: 8.5.2: Interpreting Graphs to Solve Quadratic Equations
page.contents:
Activity

Julio is solving three equations by graphing.

\((x−5)(x−3)=0\)

\((x−5)(x−3)=-1\)

\((x−5)(x−3)=-4\)

To solve the first equation, \((x−5)(x−3)=0\), he graphed \(y=(x−5)(x−3)\) and then looked for the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.

  1. Explain why the \(x\)-intercepts can be used to solve \((x−5)(x−3)=0\).

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

The solutions to \((x−5)(x−3)=0\) are \(x\)-values that make the expression have a value of 0. At the \(x\)-intercepts, the \(y\)-value of the expression \((x−5)(x−3)\) is 0, so the \(x\)-intercepts give the solutions.


  1. Graph \(y=(x−5)(x−3)\). What are the solutions?

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course.



Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The solutions are \(x=5\) and \(x=3\).


To solve the second equation, Julio rewrote it as \((x−5)(x−3)+1=0\). He then graphed \(y=(x−5)(x−3)+1\).

  1. Graph \(y=(x−5)(x−3)+1\). Then, use the graph to solve the equation. Be prepared to explain how you used the graph for solving.

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course.



Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The solution is 4 for \((x−5)(x−3)+1=0\). The solution is the \(x\)-coordinate of the \(x\)-intercept.


Solve the third equation using Julio's strategy of graphing the equations.

  1. What are the solutions to \(y=(x-5)(x-3)+4\)?

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course.



Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

There are no solutions for \((x−5)(x−3)+4=0\). The graph has no \(x\)-intercept.


Think about the graphing strategy used to solve the equations and the solutions you found. View the Desmos graphs of all three equations here.

  1. Why might it be helpful to rearrange each equation to equal 0 on one side and then graph the expression on the non-zero side?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

When a quadratic expression is equal to 0 and we want to find the unknown values, we can think of it as finding the zeros of a quadratic function, or finding the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph of that function.


  1. How many solutions does each of the three equations have?

Enter the number of solutions for each equation.

Compare your answer:

There are two solutions for the first equation, one solution for the second equation, and no solution for the last equation.


Extending Your Thinking

  1. Graph \(y=(x−3)(x−5)\) and \(y=-1\) on the same coordinate plane.

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course.

How do the equations \(y=(x−3)(x−5)\) and \(y=-1\) help solve the equation \((x−3)(x−5)=-1\)?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

The solution to \((x−3)(x−5)=-1\) is the \(x\)-value of the intersection point of the two graphs of \(y=(x−3)(x−5)\) and \(y=-1\). This solution is 4.


  1. Graph \(y=(x−3)(x−5)\) and \(y=0\) on the same coordinate plane.

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course.

How do the equations \(y=(x−3)(x−5)\) and \(y=0\) help solve the equation \((x−3)(x−5)=0\)?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

The solutions to \((x−3)(x−5)=0\) are the \(x\)-values of the intersection points of the two graphs of \(y=(x−3)(x−5)\) and \(y=0\). These solutions are 3 and 5.


  1. Graph \(y = (x−3)(x−5)\) and \(y=3\) on the same coordinate plane.

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course.

How do the equations \(y = (x−3)(x−5)\) and \(y=3\) help solve the equation \((x−3)(x−5)=3\)?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

The solutions to \((x−3)(x−5)=3\) are the \(x\)-values of the intersection points of the two graphs of \(y=(x−3)(x−5)\) and \(y=3\). These solutions are 2 and 6.


  1. Use the graphs you created in questions 1–3 to help you find a few other equations of the form \((x−3)(x−5)=z\) that have whole-number solutions.

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

There are many different answers. For example:

\((x−3)(x−5)=8\), \((x−3)(x−5)=15\), \((x−3)(x−5)=24\)


  1. Some of the values of \(z\) that you might have found are –1, 0, 3, 8, 15, 24, etc. Find a pattern in the values of \(z\) that give whole-number solutions.

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Starting at \(x=-1\), add 1, then 3, then 5, and so on, to find the next \(x\)-value that yields whole-number solutions.

Because the expressions \(x−3\) and \(x−5\) represent numbers whose difference is 2, the values of \(z\) have the form \(-1 \cdot 1\), \(0 \cdot 2\), \(1 \cdot 3\), \(2 \cdot 4\), and so on.


  1. Without solving, determine if \((x−5)(x−3)=120\) and \((x−5)(x−3)=399\) have whole-number solutions. Explain your reasoning.

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Both have whole-number solutions. The values of \(x\) that produce whole-number solutions are all 1 less than a square number.

page.title: 8.5.2: Self Check
page.contents: Use graphing technology to determine the number of solutions for the equation \((x+3)(x−6)=−22\). Then find any solutions.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Look again at the graph of \(y=(x+3)(x−6)+22\). There are no \(x\)-intercepts. The answer is that there are no solutions.

answer.answer_text: There are two solutions. \(x=-6\) or \(x=3\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Look again at the graph of \(y=(x+3)(x−6)+22\). There are no \(x\)-intercepts. The answer is that there are no solutions.

answer.answer_text: There are two solutions. \(x=-3\) or \(x=6\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Look again at the graph of \(y=(x+3)(x−6)+22\). There are no \(x\)-intercepts. The answer is that there are no solutions.

answer.answer_text: The equation has no solutions.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Look again at the graph of \(y=(x+3)(x−6)+22\). There are no \(x\)-intercepts. This means there are no solutions.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 8.5.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Interpreting Graphs to Solve Quadratic Equations

Let's analyze and interpret the graphs of different quadratic equations.

Example 1

First, let's look at the equation \((x−4)(x−7)=0\). 

We will graph the equation \(y=(x−4)(x−7)\).

This graph has two \(x\)-intercepts.

The solutions to \((x−4)(x−7)=0\) are \(x\)-values that make the expression have a value of 0. 

At the \(x\)-intercepts, the \(y\)-value of the expression \((x−4)(x−7)\) is 0, so the \(x\)-intercepts give the solutions.

The \(x\)-intercepts and solutions to the equation are 4 and 7.

Note that the values of 4 and 7 could be referred to as solutions of the equation, \(x\)-intercepts of the graph, roots of the equation, or zeros of the equation.

Example 2

Let's look at a different example. 

\((x−4)(x−7)=−2.25\)

First, we rewrite the equation to set it equal to 0. 

\((x−4)(x−7)+2.25=0\)

We will graph the equation \(y=(x−4)(x−7)+2.25\).

This graph has one \(x\)-intercept. It is an example of a double root at 5.5. A double root is a root that appears twice in the solution of an algebraic equation.

The solution is the \(x\)-coordinate of the \(x\)-intercept.

So, the solution to \((x−4)(x−7)=−2.25\) is 5.5.

Example 3

Let's look at one last example. 

\((x−4)(x−7)=-5\)

First, we rewrite the equation to set it equal to 0. 

\((x−4)(x−7)+5=0\)

We will graph the equation \(y=(x−4)(x−7)+5\).

The graph has no \(x\)-intercepts.

So, there are no real solutions for \((x−4)(x−7)+5=0\).

Remember, when a quadratic expression is equal to 0 and we want to find the unknown values, we can think of it as finding the zeros of a quadratic function, or finding the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph of that function.

Try It: Interpreting Graphs to Solve Quadratic Equations

Determine the number of solutions for the equation \((x−4)(x−9)=−6.25\). Then find any solutions.

Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course. 



Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to analyze the graph of the equation to find any solutions:

Step 1
Rewrite the equation to set it equal to 0.
\((x−4)(x−9)+6.25=0\)

Step 2
Graph the equation \(y=(x−4)(x−9)+6.25\).

Step 3
Identify the \(x\)-intercepts from the graph.
There is one \(x\)-intercept at \((6.5, 0)\).
This means there is one solution.  
The solution is 6.5.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.5.3: Choosing an Effective Strategy to Solve Quadratic Equations
page.contents:
Activity

Solve each equation. Be prepared to explain or show your reasoning.

  1. \(x^2=121\)

Enter the solution(s) to the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=11\) and \(x=-11\)


  1. \(x^2−31=5\)

Enter the solution(s) to the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=6\) and \(x=-6\)


  1. \((x−4)(x−4)=0\)

Enter the solution(s) to the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=4\)


  1. \((x+3)(x−1)=5\)

Enter the solution(s) to the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=-4\) and \(x=2\)


  1. \((x+1)^2=-4\)

Enter the solution(s) to the equation.

Compare your answer:

No solution


  1. \((x−4)(x−1)=990\)

Enter the solution(s) to the equation.

Compare your answer:

\(x=34\) and \(x=-29\)



Video: Choosing an Effective Strategy to Solve Quadratic Equations

Watch the following video to learn more about choosing an effective strategy to solve quadratic equations.

page.title: 8.5.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Solve the equation using any method covered in the lesson.

\((x−6)(x+5)=-30.25\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation is best solved by graphing. Graph the equation \(y=(x−6)(x+5)+30.25\). There is one \(x\)-intercept at \((0.5,0)\). The answer is \(x=0.5\).

That’s correct! Check yourself: This equation is best solved by graphing. Substitute 0.5 in for \(x\) and check to see if the equation is true. \((0.5−6)(0.5+5)=-30.25\). Since the equation is true, 0.5 is correct
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation is best solved by graphing. Graph the equation \(y=(x−6)(x+5)+30.25\). There is one \(x\)-intercept at \((0.5,0)\). The answer is \(x=0.5\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation is best solved by graphing. Graph the equation \(y=(x−6)(x+5)+30.25\). There is one \(x\)-intercept at \((0.5,0)\). The answer is \(x=0.5\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 8.5.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Choosing an Effective Strategy to Solve Quadratic Equations

You have learned various strategies to solve quadratic equations in different forms. If possible, try to use reasoning before graphing an equation.

Let's look at some examples.

Using Reasoning and the Square Root Property

Equations such as these can be solved by reasoning and using the square root property.

Example 1
\(x^2=81\)
\(x=9\) and \(x=-9\)

Example 2
\(x^2+7=56\)
\(x^2=49\)
\(x=7\) and \(x=-7\)

Example 3
\((x+1)^2=9\)
\(x=2\) and \(x=-4\)

Each equation above is different in some way, but they all can be solved using the same process.

Using Reasoning and the Zero Product Property

Equations such as these can be solved by reasoning and using the zero product property.

Example 1
\((x−4)(x+5)=0\)
\(x=4\) and \(x=-5\)

Example 2
\((x+3)(2x+7)=0\)
\(x=-3\) and \(x=-72\)

Using Graphing to Solve

Some equations might require graphing to be solved. One method is to rearrange the equation such that it is in the form of expression \(= 0\). Then graph \(y\) = expression, and find the \(x\)-intercepts to identify the solutions.

Given: \((x+2)(x−1)=4\)

Step 1
Rewrite the equation to set it equal to 0.
\((x+2)(x−1)−4=0\)

Step 2
Graph the equation with \(y\) = the expression that equals zero.
Graph \(y=(x+2)(x−1)−4\).

Step 3
Identify the \(x\)-intercepts from the graph.
This graph has two \(x\)-intercepts at \((-3,0)\) and \((2,0)\).

The original equation \((x+2)(x−1)=4\) has two solutions at \(x=-3\) and \(x=2\).

Try It: Choosing an Effective Strategy to Solve Quadratic Equations

Solve each equation using any method.

  1. \((x+1)^2+6=22\)
  1. \((x+3)(x−8)=0\)

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to choose an effective strategy and use it to solve quadratic equations:

Both of these can be solved using reasoning and your knowledge of properties.

  1. \((x+1)^2+6=22\)
    \((x+1)^2=16\)
    \(x=-5\) and \(x=3\)
  1. \((x+3)(x−8)=0\)
    \(x=-3\) and \(x=8\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 8.5.4: Analyzing Errors When Solving Quadratic Equations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

  1. Consider \((x−5)(x +1)=7\). Priya reasons that if this is true, then either \(x−5=7\) or \(x+1=7\). So, the solutions to the original equation are 12 and 6.

Do you agree? If not, where was the mistake in Priya’s reasoning?

Enter whether you agree or disagree and your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Disagree. Priya solved the equation using the reasoning we would use with the zero product property, but the zero product property only works if the product of two factors is 0. We can tell that 12 isn’t a solution because \((12−5)(12+1)\) is 91, not 7.


  1. Consider \(x^2−10x=0\). Diego says that to solve we can just divide each side by \(x\) to get \(x−10=0\), so the solution is 10. Mai says, “I wrote the expression on the left in factored form, which gives \(x(x−10)=0\), and ended up with two solutions: 0 and 10.”

Do you agree with either strategy? Explain your reasoning.

Enter whether you agree or disagree and your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Agree with Mai’s strategy. By substituting 0 for \(x\) and then 10 for \(x\), you can see that they are both solutions to the original equation. Diego’s strategy of dividing by a variable eliminates one of the solutions, leaving only one solution.


  1. Consider the equation \(x^2=-16\). Mona says that there are two solutions, \(x=4\) or \(x=-4\). 

Do you agree? If not, where was the mistake in Mona’s reasoning?

Enter whether you agree or disagree and your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Disagree. There are no numbers we can square to get a negative product. The equation has no solutions.


  1. Consider the equation \((x−3)(x−3)=0\). Dominic says that there are two solutions, \(x=3\) or \(x=-3\). 

Do you agree? If not, where was the mistake in Dominic’s reasoning?

Enter whether you agree or disagree and your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Disagree. Only 3 makes the equation true. The solution is \(x=3\).

page.title: 8.5.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1 and 2, decide whether each statement is true or false.

  1. \(x(x−5)=0\) has only one solution.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.5.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is false. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A solution to \(x^2−49=0\) is \(x=-7\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.5.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is true. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use graphing technology to determine the number of solutions for the equation \((x-4)(x+5)=−20\). Then find any solutions.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is two solutions; \(x=-1\) and \(x=0\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use graphing technology to determine the number of solutions for the equation \((x+2)(x+5)=−2\). Then find any solutions.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is two solutions; \(x=-3\) and \(x=-4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 5–8, choose the best method to solve the equation and then use the method to find the solution.

  1. \(x(x−6)=0\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x=0\) and \(x=6\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(\frac {1}{2}(x−4)^2=32\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x=12\) and \(x=-4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x+7)(x−2)=−8\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x=-6\) and \(x=1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((x−4)(x+9)=−42.25\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x=-2.5\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which statement is true of the equation \(x^2+36=0\)?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.5.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the equation has no solutions. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which statement is true of the equation \(x^2+9x=0\)?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 8.5.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the solutions are \(x=0\) and \(x=-9\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 8.5.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain why dividing by a variable to solve a quadratic equation is not a good strategy.
  • Explain why quadratic equations can have no solutions and explain why there are none.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 8.5.1: Reviewing Zero Product Property
    • In this activity, you reviewed how the zero product property allows you to find solutions to quadratic equations in which an expression of factors is set equal to 0.
  • 8.5.2: Interpreting Graphs to Solve Quadratic Equations
    • In this activity, you learned how to use technology to graph quadratic equations and interpret those graphs to find solutions.
    • 8.5.2: Self Check
    • 8.5.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.5.3: Choosing an Effective Strategy to Solve Quadratic Equations
    • In this activity, you practiced solving quadratic equations without any outside context about the best strategy to use.
    • 8.5.3: Self Check
    • 8.5.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.5.4: Analyzing Errors When Solving Quadratic Equations
    • In this activity, you learned to watch out for common errors made when solving quadratic equations. This includes not taking the square root of a negative number and accurately determining how many solutions an equation might have.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 8.5.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
